title-group.article-title: Investment Opportunities, Liquidity Premium, and Conglomerate Mergers*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2004 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: In this article we show that in a finitely liquid market with asymmetrically informed investors, both the benefits and the costs of diversification vary with the return and risk of the investment opportunities of the firm’s divisions. The benefits come from a reduced liquidity discount in the stock price of the merged firm when its shareholders anticipate less informed trading. The costs are the result of less efficient investment by the merged firm’s divisions due to a less informative stock price. Our results provide explanations for the life cycle of diversification strategies and implications for evaluating merger and spin‐off candidates.

fn.p: This article is a substantial revision of our earlier paper entitled “Investment Opportunities and the Informational Benefits and Costs in Conglomerate Mergers.” We have benefited enormously from the comments and suggestions made by an anonymous referee. We also thank Larry Benveniste, John Boyd, Mike Fishman, Scott Gibson, María Gutierrez, Chris Lamoureux, Vojislav Maksimovic, Paul Seguin, Raj Singh, Andy Winton, and participants at the IESE School of Business and CIIF (International Center for Financial Research) “European M&As, Corporate Restructuring and Consolidation Issues” conference (Barcelona, 2002), the University of Minnesota, and the University of Arizona, for helpful comments and suggestions. We are especially grateful to Jack Kareken and Lisa Kurz for their help in rewriting much of the article to improve its readability. All errors are our own responsibility. C. Chang acknowledges financial support from Minnesota Banking Industry Professorship Endowment, and X. Yu thanks the Center for Entrepreneurial Studies at the University of Minnesota for research support. Contact the corresponding author, Xiaoyun Yu, atxiyu@indiana.edu.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The extent to which a firm should diversify is a central issue in business organization. Although “focus” has become a fashionable word in management circles and, on average, diversified U.S. firms trade at a discount relative to their focused counterparts,1a large fraction of diversified firms (around 40% according to Denis, Denis, and Sarin1997) still trade at premiums. Researchers have also shown that historically, conglomerate mergers created value and that there is little or no diversification discount for firms in other countries.2It is therefore important to identify the economic determinants of mergers and spin‐offs that are capable of explaining why the conglomerate discount varies over time and across industries and countries.

In this article, we explore the relationship between a firm’s diversification strategy and the liquidity premium in its stock return. We believe this issue is potentially very important for the following reasons. First, the liquidity premiums due to adverse selection problems in security trading are shown to have a significant impact on stock returns. Brennan and Subrahmanyam (1996) have shown that the return difference between the most liquid shares and the least liquid ones on the New York Stock Exchange is 6.62% per year.3If the liquidity premium can be reduced by only a few percentage points, huge gains in valuation can result.4Second, by relying on changes in the two key characteristics of investment opportunities, the theory developed here is capable of explaining the life cycle of diversification strategies for many firms: from focus to diversification and then back to focus again. Third, the merger benefits identified here are the same ones as those that presumably give rise to the popularity of stock index futures and asset securitization (Gorton and Pennacchi1990; Subrahmanyam1991; Boot and Thakor1993). To the extent that these financial innovations created economic benefits, so should conglomerate mergers. Mergers may be the only way to realize the benefits when, and in countries where, the new financial instruments were less developed.

Before describing our model, it is useful to distinguish between two types of information flow between firms and the capital market. First, information flows from firms to the capital market through managerial actions when managers possess information that the market does not have. This perspective has produced many important insights in finance in the past 2 decades. However, it has long been recognized that information also flows from markets to firms (Hayek1945). In particular, security prices can aggregate decentralized and dispersed information in the economy and provide important signals for firms’ investment decisions. The information that flows from the market to firms can be referred to as “allocative information.”5Empirical evidence in the IPO (initial public offering) literature is consistent with the view that the IPO process generates a considerable amount of information about IPO firms’ growth potentials and values that is not in the security issuers’ information set. In recent years, an emerging literature in finance has recognized the importance of allocative information. For example, its efficient production has been viewed as a key factor when comparing financial systems in different countries (Allen1993; Boot and Thakor1997; Dow and Gorton1997; Rajan and Zingales1998; Subrahmanyam and Titman1999).

Our model is built on this second type of information flow. To understand the connection between the allocative information and conglomerate mergers, we construct a model of how mergers affect the way in which information about business units’ investment opportunities is conveyed by stock prices in the secondary market and how the information is then utilized in making investment decisions. In other words, what we have is a market microstructure model in which a firm’s optimal investment decision is part of the equilibrium. Such a model, while very difficult to analyze, allows us to identify both the benefits and the costs of generating allocative information. These benefits and costs are closely related to the characteristics of the firm’s investment opportunities, which we believe to be one of the major determinants of mergers.

Specifically, we investigate how a conglomerate merger of two unrelated business units affects speculators’ incentives to collect information about the business units’ investment opportunities. We characterize the conditions under which the speculators will collect information about the units with and without a merger. We show that the speculators are less likely to collect information on both units after a merger. This becomes an economic cost of a conglomerate merger if the information is valuable for making investment decisions. On the other hand, less informed trading reduces the loss to average shareholders when they have to trade for liquidity reasons. Consequently, average shareholders are willing to pay a higher price for the firm initially. The liquidity premium required by them is therefore smaller. This is the benefit of a conglomerate merger.6

The discussion above makes it clear that the cost and the benefit of a merger depend on whether the allocative information is valuable. If there is little uncertainty about the net present value (NPV) of a business unit’s project (the variance is small compared to the mean), the social value of the allocative information to the firm is small. The firm should discourage informed traders from producing this information because they gain at the expense of the uninformed investors. This can be achieved through a conglomerate merger. The model allows us to explicitly compute firms’ values under mergers and spin‐offs as functions of the means and variances of the NPVs of the two business units’ investment opportunities and the extent of investors’ liquidity shocks.

By linking the benefit and cost of a merger to the risk and return of the firm’s investment opportunities, our model can explain the life cycle of diversification strategies that many firms experience. When a young firm such as a new technology firm starts out, the uncertainty of its projects’ NPV is usually very high compared to its mean. As the firm becomes more established, the uncertainty of its NPV will decline compared to its mean. This corresponds to the stage where the demand for its product is better established and there is still little competition. Firms such as Cisco, Intel, and Microsoft are somewhere in this stage. As the firm matures and more competitors enter into its business, the mean of its NPV declines relative to the uncertainty. That is, many firms’ investment opportunities change according to the following pattern: from high return, high risk to high return, low risk and then to low return, high risk. Our model then predicts that they will start as a more focused business, then diversify into other businesses, and finally return to become more focused businesses again. This seems to be consistent with the life cycle of diversification strategies that many firms follow.7

Habib, Johnsen, and Naik (1997) first formalized the idea that spin‐offs can improve the efficiency of investment decisions when some traders have superior allocative information that managers do not have. They use a rational expectation equilibrium setup in which the price formation process is not explicitly modeled. The informed traders take stock prices as given and behave competitively. There is no cost for stock prices to convey allocative information. Consequently, spin‐offs are always preferred to mergers in their model. Chang (1998) shows that spin‐offs can increase one type of information flow at the expense of another type of information flow. Berkovitch, Israel, and Tolkowsky (2000) suggest that conglomerate mergers alleviate the agency problem through manager competition for project acceptance but reduce the ability to receive division‐specific project information from the market. The two papers do not model the price formation process either. The trade‐off is driven by agency considerations and is therefore quite different.

A number of papers have studied the relationship between market liquidity and the efficiency of decision making at the firm’s level. Holmström and Tirole (1993) show that low market liquidity induced by ownership concentration reduces market monitoring of managerial performance, which in turn lowers the level of managerial effort. Kahn and Winton (1998) and Maug (1998) investigate how market liquidity affects large shareholders’ incentive to intervene in poor‐performing firms. These papers focus on the effects of ownership concentration on stock price liquidity. In contrast, we study the effects of mergers and spin‐offs. The issue here is more difficult because we have to deal with the revelation of two types of information and examine the efficiency of investment decisions of both firms (or business units). In the IPO literature, Chemmanur (1993), Chemmanur and Fulghieri (1999), Subrahmanyam and Titman (1999), and Maug (2001) have argued that exploiting the information‐acquisition capacity of the stock market might be an important motivation for initial public offerings. Although the benefits of going public are emphasized in these papers, less attention has been paid to the cost of going public in the form of liquidity premiums. Subrahmanyam and Titman (1999) studied how information revealed in the stock prices can improve firms’ investment decisions. They are mainly interested in the comparison between intermediated financing by banks and direct financing by markets.

Although it was proposed a long time ago that internal capital markets can have an informational advantage (Alchian1969; Williamson1970), the formal analysis of the benefits and costs of internal capital markets has mainly taken the perspectives of the incomplete contracts approach (Gertner, Scharfstein, and Stein1994; Stein1997) and the agency approach (Inderst and Laux2000; Scharfstein and Stein2000; Laux2001). Much of the existing evidence shows that investment decisions made in internal capital markets are less efficient (Lamont1997; Scharfstein1998; Shin and Stulz1998). Our theoretical results are consistent with the empirical evidence. Moreover, our detailed analysis inSection IVprovides specific predictions on what types of divisions are likely to make inefficient investment decisions. Our article contributes to the literature by providing conditions under which internal capital markets form and disintegrate. It also helps us to understand to what extent internal capital markets and external capital markets are substitutes or complements.8On the normative side, our model also has important implications for capital budgeting decisions. Specifically, liquidity premiums should be part of the consideration when computing the cost of capital.

Relationships between business units are much more complicated than those captured in our model. Many other factors are important. Some of these factors have been discussed in the literature on the boundaries of the firm.9Our focus on the informational benefits and costs does not mean that they are the only important determinants of conglomerate mergers.

The article is organized as follows. The next section lays out the structure of the model. InSection III, we derive and analyze the equilibria when the two businesses units are separately traded (the spin‐off case). InSection IV, we do the same when the two units are integrated and issue a single stock (the merger case).Section Vderives explicit conditions under which a merger is optimal and the associated economic implications.Section VIdiscusses the implications of variations of the model and concludes. All proofs are in the appendix.

fn.p: See Lang and Stulz (1994), Berger and Ofek (1995), and Servaes (1996).
See, e.g., Schipper and Thompson (1983), Matsusaka (1993), Hubbard and Palia (1998), Lins and Servaes (1999), and Fauver, Houston, and Naranjo (1999).

Note that the most liquid stocks tend to be those of larger, more diversified firms, whereas the least liquid ones tend to be those of smaller, more focused firms. The return difference would be even larger if very small and highly focused firms were listed on the NYSE.

By way of illustration, we provide an example using reasonable numbers. Assume that a firm’s equity rate of return or discount rate is 12% and its (constant) dividend growth rate is 6%. With a 3‐percentage‐point reduction in the discount rate, the share price doubles; with a 4‐percentage‐point reduction, the price triples.
The usefulness of the allocative information for firms’ investment decisions can be motivated either by the fact that managers do not have it or by agency considerations. SeeSec. IIfor details.
In a recent empirical work, Huson and MacKinnon (2001) present evidence that is consistent with increased informed trading following corporate spin‐offs.

Although a rigorous empirical test is well beyond the scope of this study, one way to empirically measure the two characteristics is to use the mean and the dispersion of financial analysts’ growth rate forecasts.

Our study assumes that either there are no agency problems or the board of directors will act to veto further investments when faced with falling stock prices. This assumption may be more optimistic about the workings of internal capital markets than what is customary in this literature.
See Hart (1989), Holmström and Tirole (1989), and Milgrom and Roberts (1992) for more references.

sec.label: II.
sec.title: The Model
sec.p: Models that allow explicit analyses of the price formation process tend to be complex. In this article, a new dimension (the investment decision) is added to the standard trading models. In order to be tractable, we have to simplify everything that is not essential to the issues in which we are interested. It will become clear that the main result, merger gains depending on the two characteristics of the investment opportunities, does not rely on many simplistic features of the model.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: The Timing of Events
sec.p: We consider two unrelated business unitsMandN. There are three dates. At date 0, they can be integrated into one firm whose shares are sold to investors. Alternatively, the two units can be organized as two independent firms, and each firm’s shares are sold to investors. We will refer to the first arrangement as merger (or integration) and the second arrangement as spin‐off (or disintegration).10As in Kyle (1985), we assume that there is one trader who can collect costly information about the two business units. Whether the trader will collect information on one or both units will depend on the organizational arrangement.11

At date 1, the investors who bought shares at date 0 experience liquidity shocks, and a random fraction of them sell their shares. The informed trader can also submit trading orders. As in Kyle (1985), the orders from liquidity traders and the informed trader will be sent to market makers who set a competitive price based on the total order submitted for a stock. When the two units are disintegrated, the informed trader can trade in both firms’ shares, and there will be two stock prices.

After trading at date 1, each business unit makes its investment (or liquidation) decisions based on the information conveyed by the stock price(s). At date 2, the payoffs of the business units are realized and paid to shareholders. The details of the model and the assumptions are discussed below.

fn.p: Other methods of divesting businesses such as equity carve‐outs or issuing tracking stocks also achieve the goal of having a business unit separately traded. We believe, however, that the divestiture method in our article is best interpreted as a spin‐off for the following reasons. In order to capture the essence of tracking stocks, one needs to distinguish between earnings and assets. We are unable to accomplish this in our one‐period model. In an equity carve‐out, the divesting firm typically retains a majority stake. We do not consider the role of large shareholders in our model.

We have also considered the case in which there are two traders specializing in information collection: each trader can become informed about only one business unit. These results are available upon request.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Investment Technology

sec.label: C.
sec.title: The Informed Trader ℐ
sec.p: As discussed above, we assume that there is only one trader, ℐ, who can choose to become informed. To capture the decentralized nature of information, the identity of this trader is not known at date 0 when the organization structure is determined. That is, at date 0, neither of the two business units knows who has the access to the most accurate information needed for making the investment decisions. This will prevent them from simply hiring the informed trader to run the firm.12

By incurring a costc, the trader ℐ can learn the true realization of the NPV of a business unit’s project. If the trader ℐ would like to know both business units’ NPVs, he would have to spend 2c.13The trader is risk neutral and can submit buy or sell orders.

fn.p: This assumption, however, is not crucial if whoever runs the firm has a tendency to “build an empire” as discussed below.

For simplicity, even if the values of the two types of information are different, the information acquisition costs are assumed to be the same. This assumption does not change our results qualitatively.

sec.label: D.
sec.title: The Investors/Liquidity Traders
sec.p: To capture the effects of liquidity on date 0 valuation, we model the liquidity traders as the investors who buy shares at date 0 and who may experience liquidity shocks at date 1, as in Diamond and Dybvig (1983) and Gorton and Pennacchi (1993). Therefore, we consider only negative liquidity shocks that prompt the investors to sell their shares.14In particular, we assume that a random fraction β of the date 0 investors sell their shares at date 1. It should be noted that β is the aggregate (undiversifiable) liquidity shock for the economy. Diversifiable liquidity shocks at the individual level will be averaged out when a firm has enough shareholders. Consequently, the β that a firm (or each division after a spin‐off) faces is the same.

fn.p: Negative liquidity shocks are introduced as in Gorton and Pennacchi (1993) and Maug (1998) because from these works, we know it is easier to solve for equilibria in this setting. We see no reason why the main intuitions obtained would be affected if the positive liquidity shocks were introduced.

sec.label: E.
sec.title: The Market Makers
sec.p: The market makers are risk‐neutral agents who will set a competitive price for a stock after observing the total order submitted. They cannot separately observe the order sent by the informed trader and the orders by the liquidity traders.

sec.label: F.
sec.title: The Business Unit Managers
sec.p: We assume that the two business units,MandN, will use the information conveyed by their stock prices in making investment decisions. There are two justifications for why their managers cannot make efficient investment decisions. First, the managers (at least the top corporate managers) may not have all the information about the future conditions in the business unit’s input and output markets. Second, the managers may be well informed. However, due to the agency problem pointed out by Jensen (1986), they will prefer investment regardless of its NPV.15In this case, the board of directors or the top management will use the information conveyed by stock prices to make or approve investment decisions.

fn.p: For this to be the case, the managerial compensation schemes must be ineffective. One way would be if the managers covered are wealth constrained. In order to induce efficient investment, the managers have to be given large stakes in their firms. This may, however, be too costly to investors.

sec.label: G.
sec.title: Trading Mechanisms
sec.p: The trading mechanisms in the market microstructure literature are of two types. Included in one type are variations on the mechanism of Glosten and Milgrom (1985). Included in the other are variations on the mechanism of Kyle (1985). In a Glosten and Milgrom trading mechanism, market makers quote prices and traders trade at the quoted prices. Although this trading mechanism is quite intuitive, it is difficult to analyze informed traders’ dynamic trading strategies in this setting. Krishnan (1992) shows that at least in the binary case, the Glosten and Milgrom model and the Kyle model are identical. This allows us to concentrate on a Kyle‐type trading mechanism in order to establish a price at which the informed trader trades dependent on his trading volume. As in Gorton and Pennacchi (1993) and Maug (1998), the informed trader is allowed to submit both sell and buy orders. These orders are combined with liquidity traders’ sell orders, and the net order flow is then sent to the market makers. The market makers observe only the net order flow.16

fn.p: Different trading mechanisms may affect the informed trader’s profit and the way in which information is revealed. To demonstrate that our general results are qualitatively unchanged under alternative trading mechanisms, we analyzed another trading mechanism in which the informed trader can only submit sell orders as the liquidity traders. The total of sell orders is then sent to the market makers. The two mechanisms produce essentially the same results. We will only present the results associated with the first trading mechanism.

sec.label: H.
sec.title: The Trading‐Investment Equilibrium
sec.p: The Bayesian‐Nash Equilibrium concept is used in this article. It is essentially the same as that used in many of the market microstructure models but with one additional dimension: each business unit’s investment decision is made based on the information conveyed in its stock price, and market makers’ decisions rationally anticipate each business unit’s optimal investment decision.
Specifically, the equilibrium is defined as:

The sequence of the events is given infigure 1. Fig. 1.—
Sequence of events

sec.label: III.
sec.title: Liquidity, Investment Efficiency, and Value under Spin‐off
sec.p: In this section, we consider the case in which the two units,MandN, are two independent, focused firms, and their shares are separately traded. We derive only the results forM, the results forNbeing the same except for differences in notations.
To focus on the most interesting cases, we make the following assumption:

fn.p: We thank the referee for pointing out this general way of formulating the strategies, and, as it turns out, this class of strategies is all equilibrium strategies.

sec.label: IV.
sec.title: Liquidity, Investment Efficiency, and Value under Integration
sec.p: In this section, we study the case in which the two business units are integrated and only the shares of the integrated firm are traded. We answer the question: If the two units merge, what type of information will the informed trader ℐ gather? How does he trade?

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Acquiring One Type of Information under Integration
sec.p: We first consider case i, in which the informed trader collects only the information about ε. In this case, his trading strategies can only be contingent upon the realization of ε, and the class of the strategies that will not fully reveal his trades is the same as before: theS1 strategies.20The following result shows that, given that his choice is i, his trading profit under integration is the same as that when the business unitMis separately traded.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Acquiring Two Types of Information under Integration
sec.p: We have listed all these possible strategies intable A1of the appendix with their trading profits calculated. Note that even when a strategy yields a high profit, it may not be an equilibrium strategy because trader ℐ may be induced to deviate from it. The rational trader ℐ will play these equilibrium strategies that give him the highest profit. In what follows, we will first find the strategies that give the highest profit to the informed trader. Then we will consider under what conditions they are equilibrium strategies.
By comparing the potential informed trading profits under other candidate strategies illustrated intable A1of the appendix to these produced by theI1 strategies, we have the following result:

SinceI1 strategies yield the highest profit for trader ℐ, he will play it if it is an equilibrium. In the regions where anI1 strategy cannot be an equilibrium, we will consider the strategies fromtable A1that yield the next highest profit for trader ℐ, to see if they can be an equilibrium, and then the strategies with the third highest profit. This process will continue until all the possibilities are covered. As we will see below, we do not need to do this because most of these strategies yield a lower profit for the informed trader than that when only one type of information is collected (strategyS1).

fn.p: Notice that α here is not necessarily the same as the α in the case of spin‐off from the previous section.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Trader ℐ’s Choice of Information Acquisition under Integration
sec.p:
The informed trader ℐ is willing to play an equilibrium strategy that yields him the highest profit. To determine whether he will acquire information about ε only or about both ε and δ, we need to compare his trading profits under choice i and choice iii.
Proposition4. The informed trader’s decision to collect information under integration.
•
There is a critical cost level \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $c^{*}$ \end{document} such that, if the actual information acquisition costcis less than \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $c^{*}$ \end{document} and if parameter values fall in Ω, then trader ℐ will collect information about both ε and δ and play the equilibrium strategyI1.
•
Otherwise, trader ℐ only collects information about ε and plays the equilibrium strategyS1.

sec.label: D.
sec.title: Stock Price Efficiency and Investment Efficiency under a Merger
sec.p: When the two business units are integrated (merged), according to proposition 4, it is no longer optimal for trader ℐ to always acquire and trade on both types of information. Consequently, the informed trader’s profit as well as the informational efficiency of stock prices are lower under a merger than under a spin‐off. The lowered informational efficiency may result in allocative inefficiency in the business units’ investment decisions.

The result that mergers lead to less informative stock prices and potentially less efficient investment decisions is consistent with much of the empirical evidence concerning internal capital markets in conglomerate firms. In our model, however, this potential loss in investment efficiency is offset by the lower liquidity discount in stock returns.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Conglomerate Mergers versus Spin‐offs
sec.p: In the previous two sections, we derived the values of the two business units under a spin‐off (seeSec. III) and under in integration (see propositions 2 and 3). In this section, we first derive the conditions that determine when a merger or a spin‐off is optimal and then identify what type of firms should be the candidates for a merger or a spin‐off.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: The Conditions of a Conglomerate Merger
sec.p: Formally, a merger is optimal for the two business units if and only if

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Identifying Merger and Spin‐off Candidates
sec.p: Letiorjbe the index of a firm’s type. Define the gain/loss of merger over spin‐off between a typeifirm and a typejfirm as the difference between the merged value ofiandjminus the sum of the stand‐alone values ofiandj:

The cell with the largest value corresponds to the two types of firms between which a conglomerate merger is most likely to occur. The cell with the smallest value corresponds to the two types of units that are most likely to be split up (or remain independent).Table 2provides us with a guide.

If the merger gains in a column oftable 2are uniformly greater than or equal to those in another column, then the type of firm represented by the former column is more likely to be involved in conglomerate mergers than the type of firm represented by the latter column, other things being equal. This result is summarized in proposition 6.
Proposition6. Other things being equal, the low‐return, high‐risk type firm is most likely to be focused (or spun off). The high‐return, low‐risk type firm is most likely to be involved in conglomerate mergers if \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $m< ( 1-b) e+bd$ \end{document} .

During a business’s life cycle, the mean and variance of its investment opportunities change. According to proposition 6, its likelihood of being involved in conglomerate mergers or spin‐offs also changes. Many businesses start out as type 1 firms after their IPOs due to high uncertainty of their growth potential (internet firms, for example). If this uncertainty does not make them a failure, they often become the leader in their industries (such as Intel and Microsoft) with high profitability. This changes them to type 2 firms. As more competitors enter into their industries and their profitability drops, they turn into type 3 or 4 firms (such as IBM or Kodak). Our theory would predict that the businesses following this life cycle are likely to start out as focused firms, then to make mergers and acquisitions, and finally to break up.

fn.p: The analysis when this assumption is violated can be carried out similarly. The only difference is to use the firm’s value under integration in proposition 3 rather than that in proposition 2 in the computation below. It will not be presented here due to space limitations.

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Discussions on the economic efficiency of conglomerate mergers and spin‐offs have invariably focused on issues related to information. In this article, we establish a link between the first two moments of firms’ investment opportunities and the informational benefits and costs of mergers. We focus on the information that managers either do not have or would like to suppress due to agency problems when they make investment decisions. By explicitly building firms’ investment decisions into a market microstructure model, we have developed a theory of conglomerate mergers in which both the benefits and the costs of diversification are related to the characteristics of firms’ investment opportunities. The benefits come from a reduced liquidity discount in the stock price of the merged firm when its shareholders anticipate less informed trading in the secondary market. The costs are the result of less efficient investment by the merged firm’s divisions due to a less informative stock price.23The benefits and the costs vary with the means and the variances of the NPVs of the investment opportunities of the firm’s divisions. As the investment opportunities change over time, mergers or spin‐offs will occur in response to the changing benefits and costs. For two business units with different types of investment opportunities, we can explicitly compute the gain or loss of a merger or a spin‐off as a function of the means and variances of their investment opportunities. Our results show that it is important to distinguish between the risk and the return of the firm’s investment opportunities when talking about mergers. Our results also have implications for evaluating merger or spin‐off candidates and for empirical work on corporate restructuring.

A few assumptions of the model can be relaxed without qualitatively changing our results. One such assumption is that a single informed trader learns about both types of information. In the previous version of this article, we also analyzed the case in which there are two informed traders and each one can obtain information about one division. The results are the same except that the right‐hand side of the condition in assumption 3 is slightly different.24

A number of issues remain unanswered. For example, does a financial intermediary (such as a mutual fund) have incentives to buy shares of two separately traded business units and issue a composite security? If it does, what would be the impacts on liquidity, information revelation, and investment efficiency? We know that if the intermediary buys all the outstanding shares of the two firms, the effect is exactly like a merger. However, if it only buys a fraction of shares, this may produce an intermediate outcome between a spin‐off and a merger. An analysis along this line should be interesting.25Another related issue is capital structure. Can trading of both debt and equity achieve the same efficiency as trading of two equities? These are interesting issues for future research. Our study is only a first step in that direction.

fn.p: One may ask whether a conglomerate firm can make more efficient investment decisions by observing the information conveyed in stock prices of stand‐alone firms that are in the identical business. In our theory, such stand‐alone firms are not likely to have identical investment opportunities because otherwise, it would not be optimal for them to stand alone. They should be part of conglomerate firms.

Financial intermediation in the forms of diversified stock mutual funds and stock index trading may replicate some of the benefits of conglomerate mergers. The rapid development of these instruments in the United States may be partially responsible for the spin‐off wave in recent decades.

app.label: Appendix
app.p: Proof of proposition 1. See the text. Q.E.D.

Proof of proposition 2. One can construct a table similar totable 1with the realizations of δ added as another column (the number of rows will double due to the two realizations of δ). Since only information about ε is collected, the informed trader’s strategy is still contingent on the realizations of ε (not those of δ), and the aggregate order flows are the same as intable 1. The only difference is that the expected value of the second division,n, is added to all the market prices and final payoffs. The rest of proof follows that of proposition 1. Q.E.D.

Proof of lemma 1. When both types of information are observed, the informed trader’s strategy will be contingent on the four possible realizations of (ε, δ). In order to make his trading profitable, his equilibrium strategies should not fully reveal all of the four states. There are only two ways in which the informed trader can prevent his trade from being fully revealing: (i) his order in one state isbplus that in the other state so that the total order flow in the first state without the liquidity shock looks the same as that in the second state with the liquidity shock, or (ii) his order in each of the two states is the same.
Remark1. How the strategies are lexicographically listed:

It should be pointed out now that since the four states in the first row oftable A1are ordered from the best (highest payoff on the projects) to the worst, the informed trader’s sell order should not go down as we move from the left to the right in order to make a higher profit. That is, a strategy such as 2.1 is always dominated by a strategy such as 2.2 in which the sell order in state 4 is at least as high as that in state 3. In the listing below the third class, we will not list those dominated strategies.
The rest of expected equilibrium profits in the table are calculated similarly.

Step 3: Deriving the conditions under which deviations will not occur.—The rest of the proof derives the conditions that guarantee that this strategy is an equilibrium strategy by ruling out any profitable deviations.
Proof of proposition 5. See the text. Q.E.D.
Proof of proposition 6. See the text. Q.E.D.
